row.entry: Create a workunit from an ecl file, archive, or dll
Add a workunit to a query set
Remove a query from a query set
Run the given ecl file, archive, dll, wuid, or query
returns the full results of a given WUID in XML format.
Deactivate the given query alias name
List or manipulate queries and querysets
aborts one or more workunits from the given WUID or job name
returns the status of a given workunit or job name. If more than one is found, a list returns.
returns the workunit name from the given WUID.
returns the WUID(s) of the given workunit job name.
generate and download the zap file for the given WUID.
adds a digital signature to an ecl or text file.
returns a list of all the key user IDs that can be used by the sign command.
generate a secret name from a URL for automatic URL mapping

sect3.title: ecl.ini
sect3.para: Many options can be placed in a file called ecl.ini in the same directory as the executable. Options that do not change very often should be put in the ini file. For example:
sect3.programlisting: ;The values below are examples, you should change them to match your platform deployment eclWatchIP=10.150.50.12 eclWatchPort=28010 eclUserName=emilykate eclPassword= resultLimit=200
sect3.para: In some examples below, we'll assume ecl.ini has the above content.

row.entry: We do not recommend storing your password in the INI file or environment variable (which is clear text). The password is included in the INI file for these examples to simplify the example code.

sect3.para: The following options can be provided in an ini file: eclWatchIP, eclWatchPort, eclUserName, eclPassword, activateDefault, waitTimeout, resultLimit.
Evaluation of options follows this order of precedence:
If a username is supplied by any method, and a password is not, you are prompted for the password.

sect3.title: Environment Variables
sect3.para: Some options can be stored in Environment Variables on your machine. The following options are supported:
sect3.programlisting: ECL_WATCH_IP ECL_WATCH_PORT ECL_USER_NAME ECL_PASSWORD ECL_WAIT_TIMEOUT ECL_RESULT_LIMIT ECLCC_PATH

row.entry: We do not recommend storing your password in an Environment Variable.

sect2.title: Git Support
sect2.para: HPCC Systems integrates native support for leveraging Git.

The --main option has been extended to support compiling a query directly from a Git repository. When invoked, it retrieves the ECL code specified from the Git repository, compiles the code, and runs the query. The checkout is done on the remote ECLCCServer rather than on the client machine.

sect3.title: Syntax
sect3.para: The syntax to reference a repository location:
The #version component can be either the name of a branch, tag, or the SHA (Secure Hash Algorithm) of a commit.
For example:
ecl run thor --main demo.main@gituser/gch-ecldemo-d#version1 --server=... This example runs the demo.main ECL code in the version1 branch of the gituser/gch-ecldemo-d repository.
This feature is supported by both the ecl and eclcc command line tools.

sect3.title: Additional Examples
sect3.para: The following examples all compile the attribute demo.main from version3 branch of the GitHub repository gituser/gch-ecldemo-d:
sect3.programlisting: eclcc --main demo.main@gituser/gch-ecldemo-d#version3 eclcc --main demo.main@gituser/gch-ecldemo-d --mainrepoversion=version3 eclcc --main demo.main@gituser/gch-ecldemo-d --defaultrepoversion=version3 eclcc --main demo.main#version3 --defaultrepo=gituser/gch-ecldemo-d eclcc --main demo.main --defaultrepo=gituser/gch-ecldemo-d --defaultrepoversion=version3
sect3.para: If you are submitting a source file query.ecl, and you want it to replace the definition of demo.main with the same repo, the following will work:
sect3.programlisting: eclcc query.ecl --main demo.main@gituser/gch-ecldemo-d#version3 eclcc query.ecl --main demo.main@gituser/gch-ecldemo-d --mainrepoversion=version3 eclcc query.ecl --main "demo.main#version3" --mainrepo=gituser/gch-ecldemo-d eclcc query.ecl --main demo.main --defaultrepo=gituser/gch-ecldemo-d --defaultrepoversion=version3

sect3.title: Multiple Repository Support
sect3.para: Queries can be compiled from multiple Git repositories. Each Git repository is treated as a separate independent package. Dependencies between the repositories are specified in a package file which is checked into the repository and versioned along with the ECL code. The package file indicates what the dependencies are and which versions should be used.
In the above example, the package file gives a name to the package and defines the dependencies.

The dependencies property is a list of key-value pairs. The key provides the name of the ECL module that is used to access the external repository. The value is a repository reference using the same syntax described in the previous section.

sect4.title: External Repositories in ECL
sect4.para: To use definitions from an external repository you would add an import definition to your ECL code.
For example consider the following ECL:
The name demoRepoD in the second import matches the key value in the package.json file.
This code uses the attribute format.maskPassword from the repository gituser/gch-ecldemo-d.

Each package is processed independently of any others. The only connection is through explicit imports of the external packages. This means that packages can have modules or attributes with the same name and they will not clash.

sect3.title: The NPM
sect3.para: You can use the NPM (node package manager) to ensure that labels or branches are tied down to a specific SHA.
For example :

This command creates a package-lock.json file in the same location as package.json. The npm program then resolves the references to branches and resolves them to the corresponding SHAs. Using the --package-lock-only option indicates that the npm should not clone the associated versions of the code to node_modules directories.
The generated package-lock.json file will contain something similar to the following:
If a package-lock.json file is present it will take precedence over the package.json file. The ECL is compiled in the same way, with ECLCC Server automatically downloading the dependencies.

The advantage of using package-lock.json over package.json is that it allows you to use npm's semantic versioning syntax (#semver). It also allows you to use a branch in your package.json file as a logical dependency, but resolved to an actual dependency or specific SHA. That way if the branch is updated the query will not change.

You can also use npm without the --package-lock-only option. This will check out the appropriate version of the code into the node_modules subdirectory of the current project. The ECLCC Server supports the node_module structure as a way of providing the source for external packages. This is an alternative way to compile the code using eclcc completely independently from the source control system.

sect2.title: ecl deploy
sect2.programlisting: ecl deploy roxie findperson.ecl --job-name=FindPersonService ecl deploy roxie ArchiveQuery.xml --job-name=FindPersonService ecl deploy roxie libW20150914-125557.so --job-name=FindPersonService ecl deploy roxie - --job-name=FindPersonService
sect2.para: A hyphen (-) specifies that the object should be read from stdin.

row.entry: Creates a workunit on the HPCC Systems platform from the given ECL text, file, archive, shared object, or dll. The workunit is created in the compiled state.
The target cluster to which to deploy
The ECL text file to deploy
The workunit dynamic linked library or shared object to deploy
Specifies object should be read from stdin

This option allows you to compile queries from existing source trees or repositories. It can be used to specify default repositories and versions to use. See the "Git Support" section for specific usage.

Send ECL query to HPCC Systems cluster as text rather than gathering dependencies and building an archive
Sets the result limit for the query
Set an eclcc command line option with the single dash ('-')
Set an eclcc command line option with the double dash ('--')
Override the definition of a global attribute 'name'
Add path to locations to search for ecl imports
Add path to locations to search for system libraries
Specify path to the manifest file
Enable debug symbols in generated code
This option reports any modified attributes using git status
This option automatically downloads any missing repositories associated with dependencies
This option resolves repository references specified in directory <path>
Setting this option automatically updates repositories associated with dependencies
Displays usage information for the given command
The IP Address or hostname of ESP server running ECL services
Use SSL to secure the connection to the server.
Allows SSL servers to use self signed certificates
Path to file containing SSL client certificate
Path to file containing SSL client certificate private key
Path to file containing SSL CA certificate

The password for accessing ECL services. If you supply a username and do not supply a password, you will be promoted for a password.

sect2.title: ecl publish
sect2.programlisting: ecl publish roxie findperson.ecl --query-name=FindPersonService -A ecl publish roxie W20150914-125557 --query-name=FindPersonService -A ecl publish roxie libW20150914-125557.so --query-name=FindPersonService -A ecl publish roxie ArchiveQuery.xml --query-name=FindPersonService -A ecl publish roxie - --query-name=FindPersonService --activate ecl publish roxie findperson.ecl --query-name=FindPersonService --no-activate ecl publish roxie ArchiveQuery.xml --query-name=FindPersonService --no-activate
sect2.para: A hyphen (-) specifies that the object should be read from stdin.

row.entry: Publishes a query into a queryset. The query is created by adding a workunit to a queryset and assigning it a query name.
The target cluster to which to publish
The workunit id to publish (WUID is case-sensitive)
The ECL text file to publish
The workunit dynamic linked library or shared object to publish
Specifies object should be read from stdin
The query name to use for published workunit
The job name to use for the workunit
Does not activate query when published
Protects the workunit specified from deletion.
Specifies to not copy DFS file information for files referenced by the query
Specifies to not request a reload of the Roxie cluster
Specifies to allow the use of foreign files in a Roxie query. If a Roxie query references foreign files and this is not enabled, publish will fail.
IP address or hostname of the remote Dali to use for remote logical file lookups.
Completely replaces the existing DFS file information. This option is dangerous - only use as a last resort.
Update local DFS super-files if remote DALI has changed

Copy the files needed for the query, but don't publish the query
If all files already exist, publish the query. Otherwise, copy the files needed for the query, but don't publish the query

sect2.title: ecl queries files
sect2.para: The queries files command displays a list of the files currently in use by the given query. If the query option is omitted, it returns a list of files for all queries on the specified target.
sect2.programlisting: ecl queries files roxie myquery

para.programlisting:
> ecl queries files roxie myquery ------------------ Query: myquery Files used: jd::subfile1, 100 bytes, 2 part(s) jd::subfile2, 100 bytes, 2 part(s)
SuperFiles used: jd::mysuperfile > jd::subfile2 > jd::subfile1

row.entry: Name of target cluster on which the query is published

sect2.title: ecl queries copy
sect2.programlisting: ecl queries copy thor/findperson thor2 --activate ecl queries copy //192.168.1.10:8010/thor/findperson thor

row.entry: Copies a query from one queryset to another. A query can be copied from one HPCC Systems environment to another by using a path which begins with '//' followed by the IP or hostname and Port of the source ECL Watch and then followed by the source queryset and query.
Copy a query from one queryset to another
The path of the query to copy using the format: [//ip:port/]queryset/query or queryset/query.
The name of the target cluster to copy the query to
Use SSL when connecting to the source (default if --ssl is enabled)
Do not use SSL when connecting to source (default if --ssl is NOT enabled)
Specifies to not copy DFS file information for files referenced by the query

Process cluster to copy files from
Specifies to not request a reload of the Roxie cluster
Whether to overwrite existing information - true if present
Update local DFS super-files if remote DALI has changed
Update local clone from location if remote DALI has changed
Only use to avoid locking issues due to adding cluster to file

Specifies to allow the use of foreign files in a Roxie query. If a Roxie query references foreign files and this is not enabled, copy will fail. Prevents failure if using foreign files in Roxie query.

Specifies that DFU copy command should overwrite physical files that are already on disk.
Copy the files needed for the query, but don't publish the query
If all files already exist, publish the query. Otherwise, copy the files needed for the query, but don't publish the query

Copy both active and inactive queries. If omitted, only active queries are imported.

Specifies that DFU copy command should overwrite physical files that are already on disk.
Copy the files needed for the query, but don't publish the query
If all files already exist, publish the query. Otherwise, copy the files needed for the query, but don't publish the query

sect2.title: ecl packagemap validate
sect2.programlisting: ecl packagemap validate roxie mypackagemap.pkg ecl packagemap validate roxie --active ecl packagemap validate roxie mypackagemap.pkg --ignore-queries='findPerson*, findByZip'
sect2.para: The packagemap validate command verifies that :

listitem.para: Referenced superkeys have subfiles defined (warns if no subfiles exist)
All referenced queries exist in the current Roxie queryset
All Roxie queries are defined in the package

sect2.para: The result will also list any files that are used by queries but not mapped in the package map.
Filename, --active, and --pmid are mutually exclusive. The --active or --pmid options validate a package map that has already been added instead of a local file.

The --queryid option checks the files in a query instead of all the queries in the target queryset. This is quicker when you only need to validate the files for a single query.
ecl packagemap validate
Calls the packagemap validate command.
Actions
validate
Validates package map info
Arguments
filename
The filename containing the package map info to validate
target
The target containing the package map to validate
--active
Validates the package map that is active for the given target
--check-dfs
This option verifies that subfiles exist in the DFS
-pm, --pmid
Validates the specified packagemap
--queryid
Validate the files for the given queryid if they are mapped in the package map
--ignore-optional
Will not report optional files that are not defined in the packagemap
--ignore-warnings
Will not report general packagemap warnings
--ignore-queries=<setOfQueries>
Will not report on the queries which match the expression. The set of queries can be a comma-separated list or you can use the option once per entry. Wildcards are supported.
--global-scope
The specified package map is sharable across multiple targets
Common Options
--help
Displays usage information for the given command
-v, --verbose
Output additional tracing information
-s, --server
The IP Address or hostname of ESP server running ECL Watch services
-ssl, --ssl
Use SSL to secure the connection to the server.
--accept-self-signed
Allows SSL servers to use self signed certificates
--cert
Path to file containing SSL client certificate
--key
Path to file containing SSL client certificate private key
--cacert
Path to file containing SSL CA certificate
--port
The ECL services port (Default is 8010)
-u, --username
The username (if necessary)
-pw, --password
The password (if necessary). If you supply a username and do not supply a password, you will be promoted for a password.
--wait-connect=<Ms>

--wait-read=<Secs>
Timeout while reading from socket (in seconds)

sect2.title: ecl roxie xref
sect2.para: The roxie xref command returns file information for the specified queries on the specified cluster. If the queryids option is omitted, file information about all queries is returned. The result is in XML format.
sect2.programlisting: ecl roxie xref myroxie ecl roxie xref myroxie --queryids=myquery.1,myotherquery.1

<QueryXrefInfo> <Endpoint ep="192.168.56.1:9876"> <Queries reporting="1"> <Query id="myquery.1"/> <SuperFile name="jd::mysuperfile"> <File name="jd::subfile1"/> <File name="jd::subfile2"/> <Query id="myotherquery.1"/> <SuperFile name="jd::myothersuperfile"> <File name="jd::subfile1"/> <File name="jd::subfile2"/> <File name="jd::subfile3"/> </Queries> <Status>ok</Status> </Endpoint> </QueryXrefInfo>

row.entry: Returns file information for the selected queries in XML format.

row.entry: A bundle filename, a bundle folder, a bundle name, or a URL.
Names a branch to install when bundle references a git repository
Interprets the bundle name as a remote name from catalog
Specify a version of the bundle
Displays usage information about the given command

sect2.para: If a URL ends in .git, it is assumed to be a git repository (fetched using git clone) otherwise it is assumed to be the URL of a file that can be retrieved. In either case, it is fetched to a temporary local location, processed as a local file/directory and then removed.

sect2.title: ecl bundle install
sect2.programlisting: ecl bundle install mybundle ecl bundle install https://github.com/hpcc-systems/ecl-bundles.git ecl bundle install mybundle --dryrun ecl bundle install mybundle --update ecl bundle install mybundle --keepprior

row.entry: The name or URL of a bundle file, folder, or installed bundle.
List what would be installed, but do not copy
Install even if required dependencies missing
Do not remove any previous versions of the bundle
Interprets the bundle name as a remote name from catalog
Displays usage information about the given command

sect2.para: If a URL ends in .git, it is assumed to be a git repository (fetched using git clone) otherwise it is assumed to be the URL of a file that can be retrieved. In either case, it is fetched to a temporary local location, processed as a local file/directory and then removed.
To use the "ecl bundle install <git url>" command, you must have git installed and configured on your system. Git must be accessible to the user (in the path).

A system using ECL Server and a remote MySQL repository or ECLCC Server with git hooks can only access bundles if they are installed on the server. Using a bundle in the ECL Playground also requires installation on the ECLCC Server node.

listitem.para: In a terminal window on your ECLCC Server (or ECL Server), use this command:
sudo su hpccThis switches the user to hpcc.
Next install the bundle using this command:
Close the terminal window or use the exit command to return to acting as the original user.

Path to file containing SSL client certificate private key
Path to file containing SSL CA certificate
The password (if necessary). If you supply a username and do not supply a password, you will be promoted for a password.
Timeout while connecting to server (in milliseconds)
Timeout while reading from socket (in seconds)

sect2.title: ecl url-secret-name
sect2.para:
ecl url-secret-name
Generates a secret name from a URL for automatic URL mapping.
url
The URL to convert into a secret name.
--username
Optional. The username to associate with the URL. This will override any username embedded in the URL.
The ecl url-secret-name command generates a secret name from a URL that can be used to support ECL SOAPCALL/HTTPCALL automated URL to Secret mapping.

A username can either be embedded in the URL, such as https://username@example.com, or passed in as a parameter using the --username=username option. If a username is passed in as a parameter it overrides a username in the URL.
Passwords embedded in the URL are not needed and will be ignored.

When ECL SOAPCALL URL secret mapping is enabled SOAPCALL will convert the URL provided into a name of this format. ECL will then attempt to lookup the secret, and if found, will use the contents of the secret, rather then the original URL.
sect2.programlisting: ecl url-secret-name https://example.com --username jimi ecl url-secret-name http://example.com --username jimi

sect2.title: ecl roxie memlock

row.entry: The Roxie process cluster to memlock

sect2.para: The ecl roxie memlock command locks Roxie heap memory. This helps to prevent intermittent slow queries by ensuring that the operating system does not swap the memory out.
sect2.programlisting: ecl roxie memlock mycluster

sect2.title: ecl roxie memunlock

row.entry: The Roxie process cluster to memunlock

sect2.para: The ecl roxie memunlock command unlocks Roxie heap memory.
sect2.programlisting: ecl roxie memunlock mycluster

sect2.title: ecl roxie getmemlocked

row.entry: The Roxie process cluster to getmemlocked status

sect2.para: The ecl roxie getmemlocked command retrieves the Roxie heap memory lock status.
sect2.programlisting: ecl roxie getmemlocked mycluster
